page.title: 1998 killing of Iranian diplomats in Afghanistan

revision.text:
{{Infobox terrorist attack |title =1998 killing of Iranian diplomats in Afghanistan |location = [[Mazar-i-Sharif]], [[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan|Afghanistan]] |target = [[Iran]]ian [[diplomat]]s |date= August 8, 1998 |timezone = [[UTC]]+4:30 |fatalities = 11 |perps = [[Taliban]] |motive = }}
The '''1998 killing of Iranian diplomats in Afghanistan''' refers to the siege of the Iranian consulate in [[Mazar-i-Sharif]], in the [[Taliban]]-[[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan|controlled]] [[Afghanistan]] during the Taliban and [[Northern Alliance]] [[battles of Mazar-i-Sharif (1997–98)|battles of Mazar-i-Sharif]]. Initially the death of 8 Iranian diplomats was reported, but later two other diplomats and a journalist were also confirmed dead, bringing the total deaths to 11.<ref name="Tehran Times">{{cite journal|title=Film on 1998 Iranian diplomats’ murder in Mazar-i-Sharif premieres in Tehran|journal=Tehran Times|date=August 25, 2015|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/news/248916/Film-on-1998-Iranian-diplomats-murder-in-Mazar-i-Sharif-premieres|accessdate=7 August 2017}}</ref> The killings of the diplomats is speculated to have been carried out by [[Sipah-e-Sahaba Pakistan]].<ref name=Riedel>{{cite book|last=Riedel|first=Bruce|title=The Search for Al Qaeda: Its Leadership, Ideology, and Future|year=2010|publisher=Brookings Institution|isbn=978-0-8157-0451-5|pages=66–67|edition=2nd Revised}}</ref><ref name=Gutman>{{cite book|last=Gutman|first=Roy|title=How We Missed the Story: Osama Bin Laden, the Taliban, and the Hijacking of Afghanistan|year=2008|publisher=Institute of Peace Press|isbn=978-1-60127-024-5|pages=142}}</ref>
==Background== {{Further|Battles of Mazar-i-Sharif (1997–98)}} Before this incident, Iran was supportive of the Afghan [[Northern Alliance]], and the city of Mazari Sharif was one of the headquarters of the alliance. It is reported that between May and July 1997 [[Abdul Malik Pahlawan]] executed thousands of Taliban prisoners as a revenge for the 1995 death of [[Abdul Ali Mazari]]. "He is widely believed to have been responsible for the brutal massacre of up to 3,000 Taliban prisoners after inviting them into Mazar-i-Sharif."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1615824.stm#pahlawan |title=Afghan powerbrokers: Who's who |publisher=BBC News |date= November 19, 2001|accessdate=2011-04-01}}</ref> As a revenge, Taliban forces captured Mazar-i-Sharif and killed hundreds of Northern Alliance members, particularly members of the Hazara and Uzbek ethnic group as they were accused of being the ones who carried out the killings of Taliban prisoners.
==Events== On August 8, 1998, Taliban forces captured Mazar-i-Sharif. After this incident, 11 Iranian diplomats and a correspondent from Iran's state news agency ([[IRNA]]) were attacked at the Iranian consulate and subsequently disappeared. Unofficial reports from the city indicated that all these men were killed. Later it was confirmed that 8 of the Iranian diplomats and the IRNA correspondent were killed by the Taliban militia attacking the consulate. The Taliban spokesmen said the Iranians had been killed by renegade forces who had acted without orders.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/11/world/iran-holds-taliban-responsible-for-9-diplomats-deaths.html |title=Iran Holds Taliban Responsible for 9 Diplomats' Deaths |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=1998-09-11 |accessdate=2008-11-04 | first=Douglas | last=Jehl}}</ref> The final death toll was confirmed later to be 11 according to [[Tehran Times]].<ref name="Tehran Times" />
==Aftermath== This incident caused a public furor in Iran and many observers were worried Iran would be involved in a military response to the attack. At the time, more than 70,000 Iranian troops were deployed along the Afghan border.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/12/world/for-death-of-its-diplomats-iran-vows-blood-for-blood.html?pagewanted=all |title=For Death of Its Diplomats, Iran Vows Blood for Blood |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=1998-09-12 |accessdate=2008-11-04 | first=Douglas | last=Jehl}}</ref><ref>{{UN document |docid=S/1998/1109 | title=The situation in Afghanistan and its implications for international peace and security |session=53 |highlight=II_A_2 |page=2 |accessdate=2008-11-04 | date=23 November 1998}}</ref> Mediation by the United Nations defused the situation and all the hostages were eventually released. Later in February 1999, Iran and Taliban held talks, but Iranian-Taliban relations did not improve.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/meast/9902/03/afghan.iran.01/index.html |title=Taliban, Iran hold talks |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=1999-02-03 |accessdate=2008-11-04}}</ref>
August 8 is named ''National Journalists' Day'' in Iran, in memory of [[Mahmoud Saremi]], the IRNA correspondent killed in this attack.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://en.mehrnews.com/news/103564/Iran-marks-National-Journalists-Day |title=Iran marks National Journalists' Day |work=Mehr News |date=2014-08-08 |access-date=2018-08-06 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>

[[File:Ceuta-melilla.png|thumb|right|300px|[[Ceuta]] and [[Melilla]] on the north coast of [[Africa]].]]
The '''2007 Morocco–Spain diplomatic conflict''' was a short lived disturbance of [[Morocco–Spain relations|international relations between Morocco and Spain]] that arose after the announcement of the impending visit of the [[King of Spain]] to the Spanish-ruled autonomous cities [[Ceuta]] and [[Melilla]], which are claimed by Morocco.
The dispute formally began when the [[Government of Morocco]] recalled its ambassador to Spain, Omar Azziman. According to a diplomatic note from the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation of Morocco]], "The official announcement on Friday of the unfortunate visit of His Majesty [[King Juan Carlos I]], on 5 and 6 November to the two occupied cities of Ceuta and Melilla is a regrettable initiative, whatever are the motives and objectives."<ref name="elpais1">{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Marruecos/expresa/rechazo/viaje/Reyes/Ceuta/Melilla/elpepuesp/20071102elpepinac_16/Tes|title= Marruecos expresa su rechazo al viaje de los Reyes a Ceuta y Melilla|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= November 2, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|location= Madrid|language= Spanish|trans-title=Morocco expresses its rejection of the King's trip to Ceuta and Melilla|accessdate= December 2, 2011}}</ref><ref name="elpais2">{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Marruecos/llama/consultas/embajador/Espana/elpepuesp/20071102elpepunac_12/Tes|title= Marruecos llama a consultas a su embajador en España|date= November 2, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|language= Spanish|trans-title=Morocco calls its ambassador in Spain|accessdate= December 2, 2011}}</ref>
After reporting of calls of queries from the Ambassador, the Chief Moroccan Government Spokesperson said,"The ball is in the countryside of Spain and we hope that that country takes into consideration the sentiments of the Moroccan people and the interest of bilateral ties and cooperation."<ref name="elpais2"/>
The royal visit occurred in the days set, registering an influx of thousands of citizens, who cheered the Kings in both Ceuta and Melilla.<ref name="kingatceuta">{{cite web |url= http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/301030/0/ceuties/reciben/reyes/|title= Veinticinco mil personas recibieron en Ceuta a Don Juan Carlos y a Doña Sofía|date= November 5, 2007|publisher= [[20 minutos]]|language= Spanish|trans-title=Twenty thousand people to receive Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia in Ceuta|accessdate= December 2, 2011}}</ref><ref name="kingatmelilla">{{cite web |url= http://www.lne.es/secciones/noticia.jsp?pRef=1814_43_574968__Espana-Juan-Carlos-destaca-Melilla-sincera-amistad-vecinos|title= Don Juan Carlos destaca en Melilla "la sincera amistad de España con sus vecinos"|date= November 7, 2007|publisher= [[La Nueva España]]|location= Melilla|language= Spanish|trans-title=Don Juan Carlos highlighted at Melilla "the sincere friendship of Spain with its neighbors"|accessdate= December 3, 2011}}</ref> During those days continued statements against the visit were made by the Moroccan authorities. In this regard, the Prime Minister of Morocco, [[Abbas El Fassi]], compared the situation in both cities with the [[Israeli occupation of Palestine|Israeli occupation of Palestinian Territories]] and [[King Mohammed VI]] himself described the visit as an "outdated and nostalgic act of a dark era."<ref name="israel">{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Marruecos/equipara/Ceuta/Melilla/Palestina/ocupada/Israel/elpepuesp/20071106elpepinac_5/Tes|title= Marruecos equipara Ceuta y Melilla con la Palestina ocupada por Israel|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= November 6, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|language= Spanish|trans-title=Morocco equates Ceuta and Melilla with Israel occupied Palestine|accessdate= December 3, 2011}}</ref><ref name="condemnation">{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Mohamed/VI/condena/visita/real/advierte/Espana/consecuencias/elpepuesp/20071107elpepinac_2/Tes|title= Mohamed VI condena la visita real y advierte a España de las consecuencias|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= November 7, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|language= Spanish|trans-title=Mohamed VI condemned the royal visit of Spain and warned the consequences|accessdate= December 3, 2011}}</ref> The Spanish government, just before the visit, and after the reporting of the Moroccan opposition, told through the Deputy Prime Minister [[Maria Teresa Fernandez de la Vega]] that the visit of the King of Spain was an act of 'institutional normality."<ref name="elpais1"/> Days later, at the initiative of certain groups in Morocco, some hundreds of people carried out protests in [[Tetuan]], as well as front of the border with Ceuta and Melilla.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Cientos/personas/reivindican/Tetuan/marroquinidad/Ceuta/Melilla/elpepuesp/20071104elpepunac_2/Tes|title= Cientos de personas reivindican en Tetuán la "marroquinidad" de Ceuta y Melilla|date= November 4, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|language= Spanish|trans-title=Hundreds of people claim the "Moroccanness" of Ceuta and Melilla in Tetuan|accessdate= December 3, 2011}}</ref> Moroccan authority also discontinued high-level visits of Spanish authorities to their country.
Finally, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Spain, [[Miguel Angel Moratinos]], visited [[Rabat]] to meet his Moroccan counterpart, [[Taib Fassi Fihri]] on January 3, 2008, and presented him a personal letter from Prime Minister Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero to King Mohamed VI, which advocated for closer relations between both countries.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Moratinos/entrega/Marruecos/carta/Zapatero/dara/pie/vuelta/embajador/elpepuesp/20080103elpepunac_1/Tes|title= Moratinos entrega a Marruecos una carta de Zapatero que dará pie a la vuelta del embajador|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= January 3, 2008|publisher= [[El País]]|language= Spanish|trans-title=Moratinos delivered letter of Zapatero to Morocco will trigger the return of the ambassador|accessdate= December 3, 2011}}</ref> Four days later, the Moroccan Foreign Ministry announced the return of its ambassador to Madrid, thus terminating the conflict.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Marruecos/anuncia/regreso/embajador/frio/comunicado/elpepuesp/20080107elpepunac_6/Tes|title= Marruecos anuncia el regreso de su embajador con un frío comunicado|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= January 7, 2008|publisher= [[El País]]|language= Spanish|trans-title=Morocco announces the return of its ambassador with a cold statement|accessdate= December 3, 2011}}</ref>
==Royal visit== [[File:Juan Carlos 2004.jpg|thumb|200px|Juan Carlos I and Queen Sofia.]]
On October 30, the [[Government of Spain]] announced the visit of King [[Juan Carlos I]] and Queen [[Queen Sofía of Spain|Sofia]] to Ceuta and Melilla from 5 and 6 November. The day before, the Spanish Prime Minister [[Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero]], had told that fact to the opposition leader [[Mariano Rajoy]] during an official ceremony, which Rajoy welcomed.
The King of Spain had not visited Ceuta and Melilla in his reign. The most immediate antecedent of the stay of King Juan Carlos I in these cities dates back to 1970, when he undertook a visit to Ceuta in his capacity as [[Prince of Asturias]] on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of the [[Spanish Legion]].
The last visit of a Head of State of Spain to Ceuta and Melilla was by king [[Alfonso XIII]], who was last seen in 1927, and President of the [[Second Spanish Republic|Second Republic]], [[Niceto Alcala Zamora]], on 4 November 1933.<ref name="elpais6">{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Rey/destaca/visita/Ceuta/cumple/compromiso/pendiente/elpepuesp/20071106elpepinac_3/Tes|title= El Rey destaca que su visita a Ceuta cumple un "compromiso pendiente"|first= Tomás|last= Bárbulo|date= November 6, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|location= Ceuta|language= Spanish|trans-title=The King emphasizes that his visit to Ceuta serves a "pending commitment"|accessdate= December 16, 2011}}</ref>
The king of Spain was scheduled to visit to the autonomous city of Melilla in 1997 on the occasion of the five hundredth anniversary of the founding of the city, but the pressure of the Moroccan authorities led to the cancellation of the visit.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/299476/0/visita/oficial/reyes/|title= Los Reyes visitarán por primera vez de forma oficial Ceuta y Melilla|date= October 31, 2007|publisher= [[20 minutos]]|language= Spanish|trans-title=The King will officially visit Ceuta and Melilla for the first time|accessdate= December 16, 2011}}</ref>
On November 5, the King and the Queen of Spain stayed in Ceuta for five hours, where they spoke to the [[Assembly of Ceuta|Assembly]] of the Autonomous City, where the monarch said that he "had an pending commitment to Ceuta". Neither the king nor the Minister of Public Administration who accompanied him, [[Elena Salgado]], or any other Spanish authority made any mention of the situation in Morocco.<ref name="elpais6"/> The King was welcomed by 25,000 people.<ref name="kingatceuta"/>
On November 6, the king came to Melilla, in which the Spanish monarch intervened the [[Assembly of Melilla|Assembly]]. There he acknowledged the loyalty of Melillans to the Crown. He made specific reference to Morocco, but said that "Spain through mutual respect cultivates relations of sincere friendship with its neighbors." The number of people who gathered to welcome the King was estimated at 30,000.<ref name="kingatmelilla"/>
==Additional background of the conflict== A month before the announcement of the royal visit, the judge of the [[National Court of Spain]], [[Baltasar Garzón]], had opened a file to investigate an alleged genocide of [[Sahrawi people|Sahrawis]] by Morocco, accepting to process the lawsuit filed in 2006 by various associations defending human rights and relatives of prisoners and disappeared Saharawis, which accused 31 senior officials of Moroccan security. Morocco, meanwhile, was accused of siding with the positions of the [[Polisario Front]]. Moroccan spokesman said that "it would be good that Judge Garzon deal a bit of respect for human rights in Tindouf."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lukor.com/not-esp/internacional/0711/01115819.htm|title= Marruecos dice que Garzón debería preocuparse por los DDHH en Tinduf y no por el presunto genocidio saharaui |publisher= Lukor|location= Rabat|language= Spanish|trans-title=Morocco says that Garzon should worry about human rights in Tindouf and not by the alleged genocide Saharawi |accessdate= December 16, 2011}}</ref> Among the accused were [[Driss Basri]] and former Interior Minister and General [[Housni Benslimane]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.afrol.com/es/articulos/27106|title= Garzón abre una investigación judicial contra Marruecos|first= Derechos|last= Humanos|date= October 31, 2007|publisher= afrol News|language= Spanish|trans-title= Garzón opened a judicial investigation against Morocco|accessdate= December 16, 2011|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120213235708/http://www.afrol.com/es/articulos/27106|archive-date= 2012-02-13|dead-url= yes|df= }}</ref>
As stated by [[Yassine Mansouri]], Foreign Secret Service Chief of Morocco, during a stay in [[Mallorca]], the deterioration of relations is also related to the active position of the Spanish Government and local authorities to untie Muslim believers of Ceuta and the [[Ministry of Religious Affairs of Morocco]]; and to bet on movements like the [[Tablig]] (Congregation for the Propagation of Islam) or the [[Muslim Brotherhood]]. Mansouri informed this to [[Alberto Saiz]], Director of National Intelligence of Spain.
The position was due to the wrath of King Mohamed VI, according to Mansouri, he remembered that Moroccan King is the ''Commander of the Faithful'' and many mosques in Ceuta had been attached to the [[Union of Islamic Communities of Spain]] (UCIDE) (36 of 40 Islamic communities of Ceuta). The image of the UCID leader in Ceuta, [[Laarbi Maateis]], is associated with radical Islamist movements by Morocco. For his part, Laarbi Maateis denied any involvement with fundamentalist movements, indicating that no member of Tablig had ever been arrested or identified as a suspect in connection with [[jihadism]]. He also said the prosecution were not understandable "because the Maliki rite is practiced both here and in the rest of Spain and Morocco and no one has tried to change that, especially because it seems to be the best for the city."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://terranoticias.terra.es/provincias/ceuta/articulo/ceuta_espana_marruecos_2113293.htm|title= Maateis recuerda que el rito musulmán malekita se practica 'en Ceuta, en el resto de España y en Marruecos|date= December 11, 2007|publisher= Terra Actualidad|language= Spanish|trans-title=Maateis recalls that Maliki Muslim rites are practiced in Ceuta, in the rest of Spain and in Morocco|accessdate= December 16, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Marruecos/acusa/Espana/echar/musulmanes/ceuties/brazos/integrismo/elpepuesp/20071210elpepinac_9/Tes|title= Marruecos acusa a España de echar a los musulmanes ceutíes en brazos del integrismo|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= December 10, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|location= Ceuta|language= Spanish|trans-title=Morocco accuses Spain to drive the Muslims into the arms of fundamentalist Ceuta|accessdate= December 16, 2011}}</ref>
==Position of the Moroccan government== [[File:Mohammed VI of Morocco.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Mohamed VI.]]
The [[Prime Minister of Morocco]], [[Abbas El Fassi]], reported the Moroccan parliament that his government would not spare efforts to regain the two cities (Ceuta and Melilla). The next day, November 1, Abbas el Fassi asked the King of Spain to "waive" the trip, while the Minister and Speaker of the Moroccan government, [[Khalid Naciri]], expressed the "total rejection and condemnation" of the royal visit to "despoiled Moroccan cities." Abbas el Fassi, however, at the time said the Spanish press that there was no coercion and that the conflict "must be approached with intelligence, mutual respect, dialogue and concertation."<ref name="elpais1"/>
On November 5, while King Juan Carlos I was visiting Ceuta, Abbas el Fassi compared the situation of Ceuta and Melilla to the Israeli occupation of Palestine during a special session of the Moroccan Parliament to discuss the issue.
{{Quote|Decolonization continues to be topical in the few spots that remain in the world, including occupied Palestine, the cities of Ceuta and Melilla ....}}
The same opinion was pronounced by the leader of the Moroccan Islamist Justice and Development Party, [[Mustafa Ramid]], by manifesting in the Parliament that "the Moroccans living under Spanish colonization are as our fellow Palestinians under Israeli colonization."<ref name="israel"/>
===Manifestations of King Mohamed VI=== On November 6, after holding a Council of Ministers before intervening in the acts of commemoration of the [[Green March]] in the Parliament, Moroccan King Mohamed VI issued a harsh condemnation through a personnel spokesman:<ref name="condemnation"/> {{quotation|Strongly we express our strong condemnation and as firmly denounce this unprecedented visit. [...] Given this act was to overcome a nostalgic and dark era, the Spanish authorities must assume their responsibility for the consequences that could jeopardize the future and the development of relations between both countries. [...]}}
In the same statement Mohamed VI called for the formal opening of negotiations on the two cities: {{quotation|It is well established that the best way to resolve conflict and manage this land requires respect for the virtues of an honest dialogue, frank and open about the future, a dialogue that ensures our right to sovereignty and to take into account the interests of Spain. [...] Morocco has continued to demand an end to the Spanish occupation of Ceuta and Melilla and nearby islands in the plundered north of the kingdom.}}
===Reactions of the Moroccan government after the visit of the King=== On 15 November, the government spokesman Khalid Naciri, after a Governing Council, stated that he hoped that the Spanish "place their hand into ours to overcome the crisis and privileging our bilateral relationship. The Spanish-Moroccan relations have undergone a crisis." Do not set a date for the return of the ambassador to Madrid, insist on the need for a dialogue between the parties about the future of the Spanish autonomous cities and it is expected for the future that "our Spanish friends will consider our feelings, our sensitivity and our claims; the purpose is not to create difficulties but to preserve our relations."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Marruecos/quiere/Espana/le/coja/mano/superar/juntos/crisis/diplomatica/elpepuesp/20071115elpepunac_11/Tes|title= Marruecos quiere que España "le coja la mano" para superar juntos la crisis diplomática|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= December 15, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|location= Madrid|language= Spanish|trans-title=Morocco wants Spain "to hold their hand" to overcome diplomatic crisis together|accessdate= December 16, 2011}}</ref> However, on 16 November, the Government of Morocco suspended two high-level visits of Spanish authorities:that of the [[Ministry of Public Works and Transport (Spain)|Minister of Public Works]], [[Magdalena Álvarez]], who had planned to deal with the Moroccan Minister of Equipment and Transport [[Karim Ghellab]] about the Gibraltar rail tunnel to link the two countries across the [[Strait of Gibraltar|strait]] (an issue on which both are officially working since 2005 when Tangier was treated evolving the fixed links between Europe and Africa and Chief of Staff of the [[Army of Spain]], Admiral [[Sebastian Zaragoza]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/internacional/Marruecos/muestra/enfado/cancelando/visita/ministra/Fomento/elpepuint/20071117elpepuint_6/Tes|title= Marruecos muestra su enfado cancelando una visita de la ministra de Fomento|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= December 17, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|location= Madrid|language= Spanish|trans-title=Morocco shows its anger by canceling a visit of the Minister of Development|accessdate= December 16, 2011}}</ref>
==Position of the Spanish Government== On the same day, November 1, the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs of Spain]], [[Miguel Angel Moratinos]], who was visiting the Moroccan city of [[Marrakech]], reported orally to the Moroccan Foreign Minister [[Taieb Fassi-Fihri]], despite the manifestations of the Prime Minister, that the King of Spain would visit the cities of Ceuta and Melilla on 5 and 6 November as planned. That same day, in the usual appearance of the Government of Spain after the conclusion of the regular meeting of the Council of Ministers, the Second Deputy Prime Minister [[Maria Teresa Fernandez de la Vega]] said that relations with the Moroccan government "were extraordinary" and the journey of the Kings fell within the "institutional normality."<ref name="elpais1"/> Foreign Affairs Minister, Moratinos ruled out an action similar withdrawing the ambassador of Spain in [[Rabat]], Spanish diplomatic sources said.<ref name="elpais3">{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Mohamed/VI/retira/embajador/pone/relacion/borde/crisis/elpepunac/20071103elpepinac_1/Tes|title= Mohamed VI retira a su embajador y pone la relación al borde de la crisis|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= December 3, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|location= Madrid|language= Spanish|trans-title=Mohamed VI withdraws its ambassador and put the relationship on the verge of crisis|accessdate= December 16, 2011}}</ref>
On November 3, Defense Minister [[Jose Antonio Alonso]], in a statement to the [[Cadena SER]] said that he hoped the gesture of calling the ambassador-step prior to the breakdown of diplomatic relations, he repeated the words said by Deputy Prime Minister the previous day on the normality of the visit.<ref name="elpais4">{{cite web |url= http://www.elpais.com/articulo/espana/Parlamentarios/marroquies/convocan/protesta/Embajada/Espana/lunes/elpepuesp/20071103elpepunac_2/Tes|title= Parlamentarios marroquíes convocan una protesta ante la Embajada de España el lunes|first= Ignacio|last= Cembrero|date= November 3, 2007|publisher= [[El País]]|location= Madrid|language= Spanish|trans-title=Moroccan parliamentarians convened a protest outside the Embassy of Spain on Monday|accessdate= December 16, 2011}}</ref>
The Minister of Foreign Affairs expressed on November 14 its confidence in the return of the Moroccan ambassador in Madrid "as soon as possible."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/ElFinanciero/Portal/cfpages/contentmgr.cfm?docId=90114&docTipo=1&orderby=docid&sortby=ASC|title= Confía Moratinos en rápido fin de la crisis con Marruecos|publisher= El Financiero|language= Spanish|trans-title=Moratinos confident quick end to the crisis with Morocco|accessdate= December 16, 2011|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080612084731/http://www.elfinanciero.com.mx/ElFinanciero/Portal/cfpages/contentmgr.cfm?docId=90114&docTipo=1&orderby=docid&sortby=ASC|archivedate= June 12, 2008|deadurl= yes}}</ref>
==Political reactions==
===Political reactions in Spain=== The [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]] and [[United Left (Spain)|United Left]] political parties, through [[Angel Acebes]] and [[Gaspar Llamazares]], respectively, announced their support for the visit of the King of Spain to Ceuta and Melilla.<ref name="elpais1"/> [[Gustavo de Arístegui]], of the People Party, termed Mohamed VI's reaction as "excessive" and criticized the Spanish Prime Minister for failing to make clear, in his view, the 'red lines' that Morocco could not cross.<ref name="elpais3"/> Meanwhile, [[Elena Valenciano]], International Relations Secretary of the [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]], stressed that the visit was part of "the most absolute institutional normality."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.europapress.es/00069/20071102152534/marruecos-psoe-cree-desafortunados-algunos-comentarios-rabat-visita-reyes-ceuta-melilla.html|title= PSOE cree desafortunados algunos comentarios de Rabat sobre la visita de los Reyes a Ceuta y Melilla|date= November 2, 2007|publisher= [[Europa Press (news agency)|Europa Press]]|language= Spanish|trans-title=PSOE believes Rabat's certain comments on the visit of the Kings to Ceuta and Melilla as unfortunate|accessdate= December 25, 2011}}</ref>
The [[President of Melilla]], [[Juan José Imbroda]], said that "it is not the time to make opposite sounding declarations", in reference to the Moroccan position.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://terranoticias.terra.es/provincias/melilla/articulo/imbroda_marruecos_recuerda_visita_real_1983880.htm|title= Imbroda recuerda a Marruecos que la visita real sólo atañe a los españoles|date= November 3, 2007|publisher= Terra Actualidad|language= Spanish|trans-title=Imbroda reminds Morocco that the royal visit only involves the Spanish|accessdate= December 25, 2011}}</ref> [[Coalition for Melilla]], the prime Muslim-based opposition party in the autonomous city, manifested itself as extremely pleased with the visit the King, adding that the presence of the King of Spain was a "historic debt in this city and which, from this formation, we always advocate for the occurrence of the visit."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://terranoticias.terra.es/articulo/coalicion_melilla_rey_1983763.htm|title= Coalición por Melilla muestra su 'satisfacción' por la visita del Rey pero crítica que no se cuente con la oposición|date= November 3, 2007|publisher= Terra Actualidad|language= Spanish|trans-title=Coalition for Melilla shows its "satisfaction" for the King's visit but not critical on the opposition count|accessdate= December 25, 2011}}</ref> For his part, the [[President of Ceuta]], [[Juan Jesus Vivas]], merely issued an edict in which he urged the citizens to welcome the King, honor him by the presence of Ceutans, and "you will honor yourselves, our city and our beloved country."<ref>{{cite web |title=Vivas pide a los ceutíes que rindan un 'homenaje de adhesión' a los Reyes |url=http://terranoticias.terra.es/nacional/articulo/vivas_reyes_ceuties_rindan_homenaje_1983652.htm |date=November 3, 2007 |publisher=Terra Actualidad |language=Spanish |trans-title=Vivas asks Ceutans to hold a "tribute accession" for the King |accessdate=April 7, 2013}}</ref>

page.title: 2008 US beef protest in South Korea

revision.text:
{{citation style|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} [[File:080503 ROK Protest Against US Beef Agreement 05.jpg|thumb|250px|Protesters lit up their candles in downtown Seoul, 3 May 2008.]] [[File:080606 ROK Protest Against US Beef Agreement 03.jpg|thumb|250px|A close up picture of Candle-light girl, an iconic character created by protest organizers. The slogan reads, "All candles together, till our goals achieved". Photo taken in front of [[Seoul City Hall]] on 6 June 2008.]] The '''2008 US beef protest in South Korea''' was a series of protest demonstrations between 24 May 2008 and about 18 July 2008 in [[Seoul]], [[Korea]]. At its height, the protest involved tens of thousands of people. The protest began after the South Korean government reversed a ban on US beef imports. The ban had been in place since December 2003, when the [[prion]] responsible for [[bovine spongiform encephalopathy]] (BSE), or 'mad cow disease' was detected in US beef cattle.{{cite news | last= | first= | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7491482.stm | title= Thousands in S Korea beef protest | publisher= [[BBC news]] | date= 5 July 2009| accessdate= 11 June 2012}} The protests occurred on a background of talks concerning the [[KORUS FTA|US-Korea free trade agreement]]. Unrest was fanned by local media reports such as the [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation]] (MBC) ''[[PD Notebook]]'' program "Is American Beef Really Safe from Mad Cow Disease?" televised on 27 April 2008.{{cite news | last= | first= | url= https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2009/06/117_26501.html | title= MBC's overdue apology | publisher= ''[[Korea Times]]'' | date= 25 June 2009 | accessdate= 11 June 2012}} == Background == Controversy in South Korea over U.S. beef isn't new, but has been largely dormant for the past four years. In 2008, the then new Lee Myung-bak government agreed, after extensive negotiations, to restart imports, which had been halted since cases of mad cow disease were found in the United States in 2003.{{Cite web|url=http://thediplomat.com/2012/05/south-koreas-new-beef-with-u-s/|title=South Korea's New Beef with U.S.|last=Diplomat|first=Steven Borowiec, The|website=The Diplomat|access-date=2016-03-08}} That decision set off a firestorm of controversy, leading hundreds of thousands of citizens to come out in the spring and early summer of 2008 in protest over the resumed imports. Sensationalist media reports and online rumors fueled speculation that the new president was recklessly putting South Koreans' health at risk of contracting bovine spongiform encephalopathy, better known as mad cow disease. The deal has sparked public outrage amid widespread perceptions, fanned in part by sensational media reports, MBC PD Notebook, that it exposes the country to a higher risk of mad cow disease.https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/30/world/asia/30korea.html?_r=0 ==Origin of the protest== ===2003=== On 23 December 2003, a first case of BSE in the US was found in Washington state. The Holstein cow had been imported from Canada in 2001. On 9 December the 6.5-year-old cow was slaughtered. The cow was a "downer" (a cow that is unable to walk). For that reason, the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) was automatically notified; and the cow was examined before and after its death by a government vet. The vet determined that the cow was suffering from complications of calving. Samples of tissue were taken for further testing for BSE. Parts of the cow with a high risk of transmitting the BSE prion were removed but may have been sent for "inedible rendering" into food for non-ruminant animals. The carcass itself was allowed to continue on for further processing into human food at other facilities. On 23 December 2003 when tests proved positive for BSE, a recall was made. The contaminated meat had not entered the commercial market. Offspring of the cow were destroyed.[https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5253a2.htm] "Bovine spongiform encephalopathy in a dairy cow – Washington State, 2003". 9 January 2004. ''Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report'', 52(53);1280–1285. Centre for disease control and prevention. Retrieved 11 June 2012. South Korea, Japan, Singapore, Malaysia and Taiwan banned imports of US beef.[http://edition.cnn.com/2003/BUSINESS/12/23/japan.madcow.reax/] "Countries move to ban U.S. beef" CNN International. 24 December 2003. Retrieved 11 June 2012. The head of the US FDA at the time was Ann M. Veneman, a former lobbyist for the food industry.[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/13/opinion/13krugman.html] "Bad cow disease." Krugman, Paul. 13 June 2008. ''New York Times'' Accessed 11 June 2012. ===2006=== By 2006, sixty-five nations had full or partial restrictions on the importation of US beef. Export sales of US beef fell from $3.8 billion in 2003 to $1.4 billion in 2005.[https://www.usatoday.com/news/opinion/editorials/2006-08-03-our-view_x.htm] "Mad cow watch goes blind." Editorial, ''USA Today'' 3 August 2006. Retrieved 11 June 2012. An attempt to reopen the South Korean market to US beef imports in 2006 (restricted to boneless meat from cattle less than 30 months old) failed when the South Korean government discovered bone chips in a shipment of 3.2 tons of meat.[http://www.thebeefsite.com/bse-news/14140/] "Second Shipment of U.S. Beef Rejected." 2 December 2006. Thebeefsite.com. Farm week. 5M enterprises. Retrieved 11 June 2012. Sporadic attempts made in the following year also failed for similar reasons.[http://www.thebeefsite.com/news/16868/s-korea-us-to-hold-technical-meeting-on-us-beef] "S. Korea, U.S. to hold technical meeting on U.S. beef." 30 April 2007. Thebeefsite.com. Farm week. 5M enterprises. Retrieved 11 June 2012. ===2008 – Lee's reversal of the beef import ban=== On 17 January 2008 representatives of the president of South Korea met with [[Alexander Vershbow]], the U.S. ambassador to South Korea to discuss beef imports.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/09/116_94355.html] "Lee made beef deal before Bush talks in 2008." Igiauer, Phillip, 9 June 2011. ''Korea Times'', National desk. Retrieved 11 June 2012. Further talks were held between 11 and 17 April 2008. On 18 April U.S. and South Korean negotiators reached an agreement on the sanitary rules that Korea would require of U.S. beef imports. The agreement allowed imports of all cuts of U.S. beef (both boneless and bone-in) and certain beef products, including those from cattle over 30 months old. Processors had to remove material known to risk BSE prion transmission.[http://www.nationalaglawcenter.org/assets/crs/RL34528.pdf] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311121101/http://www.nationalaglawcenter.org/assets/crs/RL34528.pdf |date=11 March 2012 }} "U.S.-South Korea Beef Dispute: Issues and Status." Jurenas, Remy (Specialist in Agricultural Policy) and Manyin, Mark E. (Specialist in Asian Affairs). 23 September 2010. Congressional research service. Retrieved 11 June 2012. President Lee visited President George W. Bush at [[Camp David]] on 20 April 2008. The U.S. reported,
President Bush welcomed the decision of the Korean government to resume the import of U.S. beef, based on international standards and science. The two presidents pledged to make every effort to urge their respective legislatures to approve the KORUS FTA (Korean US Free trade agreement) within this year.[http://asiafoundation.org/resources/pdfs/ROKUSSummitFullTextApr08.pdf] "Full Text of S. Korea-U.S. Summit Statement" 20 April 2008. The Asia Foundation. Retrieved 11 June 2012.
Demonstrators accused Lee of reversing the ban on imports of U.S. beef in haste, giving the U.S. unwarranted concessions, so that Korea would receive a favorable reception, particularly with respect to ratifying the proposed free trade agreement. The demonstrators said Lee had abandoned his duty of care to the people of South Korea for political gain by ignoring their concern about BSE prion transmission and by lowering tariffs on imported beef.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7457087.stm] "Question and answer: South Korea beef protests" BBC news. 25 June 2008. Retrieved 11 June 2012.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/09/116_94355.html] "Lee made beef deal before Bush talks in 2008" Igiauer, Phillip, ''Korea Time'', National desk. 9 June 2011. Retrieved 11 June 2012. Korea agreed to remove a 40% tariff on beef muscle meat imported from the U.S. for a period of 15 years. Korea could however, impose temporary tariffs if there was a surge of U.S. beef imports above specified levels.[https://fpc.state.gov/documents/organization/112467.pdf] "The proposed U.S.-South Korea free trade agreement (KORUS FTA): provisions and implications" 17 October 2008. Cooper W. et al. Congressional research service report. Retrieved 11 June 2012. ==MBC "PD Notebook" program== On 27 April 2008, MBC televised a program called "Is American Beef Really Safe from Mad Cow Disease?" The program precipitated mass demonstrations. After a complaint was received from the South Korean agriculture ministry, the Seoul central prosecutors' office formed a team of five to investigate the program's content.[http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2891646] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130127065553/http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2891646 |date=27 January 2013 }} "Prosecutors expanding probe into TV report". Ser, Myo-ja, staff reporter. 27 June 2008. ''Korea Joongang Daily''. Retrieved 12 June 2012. ===Downer cows=== ''Downer'' cows are animals presented for slaughter that are sick or unable to walk. One of many causes for a downer is BSE. MBC was criticised for broadcasting footage of downer cows with translated subtitles that suggested they suffered from BSE, whereas they were filmed because of animal cruelty concerns, not BSE.[http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2892992] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130126202607/http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2892992 |date=26 January 2013 }} "Prosecutors say PD Diary deliberately twisted facts." Ser, Myo-ja, staff reporter. 30 July 2008. Retrieved 12 June 2008. ===Aretha Vinson=== Aretha Vinson was a 21-year-old student at Virginia state university. She died on 9 April 2008 of [[Wernicke's encephalopathy]].[http://www.foodhaccp.com/1news/040809k.html] "Woman on 'PD Diary' did not die of mad cow." 7 April 2009. "Food safety information website". Retrieved 12 June 2012. The MBC broadcast showed footage of Vinson's mother speaking about her daughter's illness. Translated subtitles suggested Vinson had vCJD, but that was only one initial diagnostic possibility. ===Risk of US beef to South Korea=== Concerns that some commentators raised about the program included, MBC's statements about a genetic vulnerability of Koreans to CJD;[http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2008/05/09/2008050961017.html] "Mad cow thesis twisted out of all proportion." Editorial. 9 May 2008. ''The Chosunilbo'' English edition. Retrieved 16 June 2012 the US exporting cattle over 30 months old to Korea rather than selling it to the domestic market;[http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2008/05/07/2008050761023.html] "The medium is the monster." Yang, Sang-hoon. 7 May 2008. ''The Chosunilbo'' English edition. Retrieved 16 June 2012 and, the risk of contracting CJD by consuming beef products such as powdered soup base in instant noodles, cosmetics, and gelatin medication.[http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2008/06/27/2008062761027.html] "What to do about media fabrications." Editorial. 27 June 2008. ''The Chosunilbo'' Accessed 16 June 2012 == Reaction to "PD Notebook" == Demonstrations involving tens of thousands of people began shortly after the first broadcast, and increased when MBC aired another segment two weeks later. ===Korean communications commission=== MBC became the subject of legal action. On 12 August 2008, the [[Korea Communications Commission]] called for MBC to apologise to the public over misrepresentations made in the PD notebook program.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/08/113_29254.html] "MBC offers apology over US beef report." ''Korea Times'' 13 August 2008. Retrieved 13 June 2012. MBC apologised a two-minute broadcast, saying,
We would like to offer a sincere apology to our viewers [over the report].
MBC conceded that six translation errors had been made and that downer cattle had been mistakenly identified as suffering from BSE.[https://archive.is/20121210143445/http://www.asiamedia.ucla.edu/article-eastasia.asp?parentid=95873] "MBC offers apology over US beef report." ''Korea Times''. Asia media archives. Retrieved 13 June 2012. ===MBC versus Government=== The government of South Korea directed its prosecutors office to investigate alleged actions of the MBC including mis-representations made by the PD Notebook program; aggravation of civil unrest; and, defamation of the minister for agriculture. In June 2009, four producers and one writer were indicted on the charges.[https://www.amnesty.org/en/region/south-korea/report-2010] "South Korea – Amnesty International Report 2010." Accessed 13 June 2012. In January 2010, the MBC staff were exonerated by judges of the Seoul central district court.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/03/117_59384.html] "Court declares MBC not guilty on mad cow report in 2008." Park, Si-soo staff reporter. 20 January 2010. ''The Korea Times''. Retrieved 13 June 2012. The supreme court upheld the findings.[http://view.koreaherald.com/kh/view.php?ud=20110902000758&cpv=0] "Supreme Court clears 'PD Notebook' of distortion." Bae, Ji-sook. ''Korea Herald''. 9 February 2011. Retrieved 13 June 2012. =="Candlelight" demonstrations== [[File:Korea-Myungbak sanseong-01.jpg|thumb|250px|Stacked shipping containers in downtown Seoul blocking [[Sejongno|Sejong avenue]], which leads to the South Korean Presidential residence the [[Blue House]]. Photo taken on 12 June 2008.]] [[File:080606 ROK Protest Against US Beef Agreement 04.jpg|thumb|250px|Mass protesters occupied [[Seoul Plaza]] in front of [[Seoul City Hall]]. Photo taken on 6 June 2008.]] [[File:080607 ROK Protest Against US Beef Agreement 08.JPG|thumb|250px|Internet news media [[Ohmynews]] broadcasting live protest in the street.]] Some commentators argue that there is a long-held and perpetual "culture of protest" in South Korea involving groups ranging from anarchists to social reformers.[http://populargusts.blogspot.com.au/2008/06/herald-on-candlelight-rallies-in-2002.html] "Gusts of popular feeling" eBlogger, 13 June 2008. Retrieved 14 June 2012. Anti US beef protests began on 24 May 2008. After the MBC ''PD Notebook'' broadcast, the US beef protests in Seoul increased. A three-day demonstration held in relay took place from 5 June 2008 to 7 June 2008.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/include/print.asp?newsIdx=25402] "Citizens, students, unionists start 3-day rally." Kang, Shin-woo. 5 June 2008. ''Korea Times''. Retrieved 15 June 2012. Attendance peaked on the evening of 10 June 2008, (80,000 protestors in attendance) before declining.[http://abcnews.go.com/video/playerIndex?id=5046168] "No more U.S. beef: 80-thousand people protested against U.S. beef in Seoul." 6 November 2008. ABC news. Retrieved 16 June 2012. (Photographs depicting the demonstrations from "Reuters", "Getty Images" and "AFP" are published [http://www.boston.com/bigpicture/2008/06/south_korean_protests_over_us.html here.]) ===Influence of social media=== Internet and text messaging also assisted in publicising the movement. With ready access to social media, among the first to protest were teenage schoolgirls. A teenage schoolgirl holding a lit candle became the symbol of the anti-US beef protests.[http://www.economist.com/node/11554714] "Ill met by candlelight" 12 June 2008. ''The Economist''. Retrieved 14 June 2012 Comments made by some protestors had little basis in science.[http://in.reuters.com/article/2008/06/13/us-korea-politics-internet-idINSEO30506420080613?sp=true] "South Korean Internet catches "mad cow madness"" Jon Herskovitz and Rhee So-eui. Reuters. 13 June 2008. Retrieved 14 June 2012. ===The demonstrators=== After the initial demonstration, the area in front of Seoul's city hall, as well as the adjoining streets, were occupied by demonstrators. Early in the protest, a festival like atmosphere prevailed as protesters of all walks of life, built a makeshift tent city on the lawn at [[Seoul Plaza]].[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/06/117_25435.html] "Gone is solemnity at rallies" Kim, Rahn. Staff reporter. ''Korea Times'' 6 June 2008. Retrieved 15 June 2012. However, some massive, disruptive and sometimes aggressive demonstrations and street marches were held each night, particularly at weekends.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/06/117_25901.html] "Seoul plaza suffering under mass rallies" 15 June 2008. ''Korea Times''. Retrieved 14 June 2012 Thus, the protest had two faces: more peaceful during the day and more violent at night.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/06/113_25498.html] "Anti-US beef rallies have two faces." Kim, Rahn. ''Korea times''. 8 June 2008. Retrieved 15 June 2012. About 200 protestors required hospital treatment.[http://www.ndtv.com/convergence/ndtv/story.aspx?id=NEWEN20080054939&ch=June%2029,%202008%204:46:00%20PM] "Over 200 injured in S. Korea beef protests." AFP. 29 June 2008. Retrieved 15 June 2012. ===Police action=== On 1 June 2008, police took action to control demonstrators. Buses and shipping containers were used to halt the progress of street marches. A barrier of shipping containers were erected across Sejong-Ro to stop marchers from reaching [[Cheongwadae]] (office and residence of the president). The protestors named the barrier, "Myung-bak's Fortress" and decorated it with leaflets and large Korean flags. They photographed themselves standing on the barrier. It was dismantled several days later without conflict.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/06/117_25722.html] "Container barricade draws spotlight." Park, Si-soo. 11 June 2008. ''Korea times''. Retrieved 15 June 2008. Water cannons were used to suppress protestors. Some demonstrators were detained for questioning.[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/24818417/ns/business-world_business/t/south-koreans-protest-us-beef-imports/#.T9p3gY6XvzI] "Rally against a beef import agreement brings clashes with police." World business. Associated press. 25 May 2008. Retrieved 15 June 2012.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/06/119_25651.html] "Container barricade blocks demonstrators." Kim, Tae-jong. 10 June 2008. ''Korea times'' Accessed 15 June 2012. The [[Amnesty International]] report on the human rights aspects of the demonstrations is published [https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/asa25/008/2008/en/ here.] The report said,
The protests were for the most part peaceful and given its size and duration, both the protesters and the police showed notable organization and restraint. However, there were sporadic incidents of violence, as riot police and protesters clashed. The two main flashpoints of violence occurred on 31 May/1 June, when the police first used water cannons and fire extinguishers, and 28/29 June, the weekend following the government's announcement that US beef imports would resume. The decision to use water cannons and fire extinguishers contributed to the mass resignation of all 14 members of the Korean National Police Agency's human rights committee.[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/asa25/008/2008/en/] "Policing the candlelight protests in South Korea". Amnesty International. 25 August 2008. Retrieved 15 June 2012
==Effects of the protests== [[Image:Australianbeef.JPG|thumb|right|250px|A fast food restaurant in Seoul reassuring customers that they are using "clean beef from Australia".]] ===Korean government=== The [[approval rating]] of Lee fell below 20%. Prime Minister Han Seung-soo and other cabinet members submitted their resignations to President Lee.[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/10/world/asia/10korea.html?_r=1&hp&oref=slogin] "S. Korean cabinet offers to quit after beef protests" Choe, Sang-hun. 10 June 2008. ''The New York Times'' Accessed 15 June 2012 On 22 May and then again on 18 June 2008, Lee apologised for ignoring public health concerns.[https://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSSEO20019820080602] "South Korea delays resumption of U.S. beef imports." Reuters. 2 June 2008. Retrieved 15 June 2008. Lee said,
I should have paid attention to what people want. Sitting on a hill near Cheongwadae on the night of 10 June, watching the candlelight vigil, I blamed myself for not serving the people better.
Lee also delayed the announcement of any further relaxation of beef importation rules, for example, importation of meat from cattle over 30 months of age. On 2 July 2008, [[Han Seung-soo]], [[Prime Minister of South Korea]] bought 260,000 [[Korean won]] (roughly US$230–$260) worth of U.S. [[steak]] to eat with his family at his official residence to alleviate public worries about U.S. beef. The same amount of Korean beef would have cost approximately 800,000 [[Korean won]] (roughly $700–$800, three times more expensive than imported U.S. beef).[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/4fc507ec-4852-11dd-a851-000077b07658.html] "Seoul struggles to defuse US beef imports." Fifield, Anna. ''Financial Times''. 2 July 2008. Retrieved 15 June 2012. ===US=== On 22 June 2008, an American trade envoy headed by Susan C. Schwab, agreed with the Korean prime minister and agriculture minister to limit the export of meat to that from carcasses of cattle less than 30 months old with government certification of their age and to allow Korea to inspect a sample of U.S. slaughterhouses. The agreement also included the banning of importation to Korea of meat from cattle organs considered high risk for transmission of the BSE prion such as brains, eyes, skulls and spinal cord. Schwab said,
We look forward to safe, affordable, high-quality American beef – the same beef enjoyed by hundreds of millions of U.S. consumers and people in countries around the world – soon arriving on Korean tables.[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/22/world/asia/22korea.html] "South Korea and US reach deal on beef imports." Choe, Sang-hun. 22 June 2008. ''New York Times'' Accessed 15 June 2012
[[Tom Casey (diplomat)|Tom Casey]], deputy spokesman at the [[U.S. State Department]] rejected the notion that the U.S. had bullied S. Korea into removing the 2003 ban on U.S. beef imports and said,
[The U.S. and S. Korea] have a long history of military and security cooperation. I don't think this or any other individual issues are going to change the fundamental relations (between the two countries).[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/07/116_26799.html] "US reconfirms strong alliance with S. Korea despite beef crisis." 1 July 2008. ''The Korea Times'' Accessed 15 June 2012
From December 2009 to December 2010 the US meat export federation (USMEF) used a 3 phase project called, "To trust". It was an image campaign, designed to increase the trust of Koreans in US beef. It depicted three women who were mothers and homemakers. One was a rancher, one a scientist and one a food safety inspector.[http://www.beefissuesquarterly.com/free-tradeagreementwillsupportusbeefrecoveryinsouthkorea.aspx] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120129061558/http://www.beefissuesquarterly.com/free-tradeagreementwillsupportusbeefrecoveryinsouthkorea.aspx |date=29 January 2012 }} "Free trade agreement will support US beef recovery in South Korea." Halstrom, Dan. Senior vice president of global marketing & communications – U.S. meat export federation. ''Beef issues quarterly'' 2012. Retrieved 15 June 2012. ===Hi! Seoul festival=== In 2009, a small number of demonstrators commemorated the anniversary of the 2008 protests. They forcibly occupied the [[Hi! Seoul Festival]] stage in front of the city hall in central Seoul. The police removed the protestors.[http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2904347] "Hi Seoul' opening hit by protests from past." Jang, Joo-young and Lee, Min-yong. 4 May 2009. Retrieved 15 June 2012 ===Commentators=== Kim Dae-joong (not to be confused with former Korean President and [[Nobel Peace Prize]] winner [[Kim Dae-jung]]), a columnist at the ''Korea Times'', wrote in his editorial piece: "It amounts to double-crossing to be really fond of America in all substantive matters, while bad-mouthing America in public protests."[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/include/print.asp?newsIdx=24696] "beef and anti-Americanism." Huer, John. ''The Korea times'' 25 May 2008. Retrieved 15 June 2012 ==US beef imports in South Korea== On 1 July 2008, U.S. beef imports resumed. In 2009, the US exported 141 million lbs of beef to South Korea worth $215 million.[http://www.ers.usda.gov/news/BSECoverage.htm] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120611042414/http://www.ers.usda.gov/news/BSECoverage.htm |date=11 June 2012 }} "U.S. beef and cattle industry: background statistics and information." 25 April 2012. Economic Research Service. United States Department of Agriculture. {{pp-30-500|small=yes|expiry=indef}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} [[File:Melbourne Gaza protest Zionist Criminals, End the Palestine Holocaust.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Protest against the [[Gaza War (2008–09)|Gaza War]] in [[Melbourne]], 2009]] [[File:Neturei karta2.jpg|thumb|right|On 7 September 2006 in [[Trafalgar Square]], [[London]].]] '''Anti-Zionism''' is opposition to [[Zionism]]. The term is broadly defined in the modern era as the opposition to the [[ethnonationalist]] and political movement of [[Jews]] and [[Jewish culture]] that supports the establishment of a [[Jewish state]] as a [[Jewish homeland]] in the territory defined as the historic [[Land of Israel]] (also referred to as [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], [[Canaan]], or the [[Holy Land]]). Anti-Zionism is also defined as opposition to the [[State of Israel]]. The term is used to describe various religious, moral and political points of view, but their diversity of motivation and expression is sufficiently different that "anti-Zionism" cannot be seen as having a single ideology or source. There is also a difference between how it is discussed philosophically and how it is enacted within a political or social campaign.Halpern, Gilad, host. [https://tlv1.fm/the-tel-aviv-review/2017/11/17/left-handed-compliments-anti-semitic-discourse-among-progressives/ "Left Handed Compliments ...."] ''The Tel Aviv Review'', TLV1 Podcasts. 17 November 2017. See discussion beginning at 22:33. Many notable Jewish and non-Jewish sources take the view that anti-Zionism has become a cover for modern-day [[antisemitism]], a position that critics have challenged as a tactic to silence [[criticism of the Israeli government|criticism of Israeli policies]]. Others, such as [[Steven M. Cohen]], [[Brian Klug]][[Brian Klug]], [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/dec/03/comment No, Zionism is not anti-semitism] [[The Guardian]] 3 December 2003 and [[Todd Gitlin]], see no correlation between the two. ==History== {{main article|Timeline of anti-Zionism}} {{see also|History of Zionism|History of antisemitism}} ==Jewish anti-Zionism== Jewish anti-Zionism is as old as Zionism itself, and enjoyed widespread support in the Jewish community until World War II.[[Mike Marqusee]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=2llC2XJgwdwC&pg=PR7 ''If I Am Not For Myself: Journey of an Anti-Zionist Jew,''] [[Verso Books]] (2008) 2010 p.vii:’As long as there has been Zionism, there have been anti-Zionist Jews. Indeed, decades before it even came to the notice of non-Jews, anti-Zionism was a well-established Jewish ideology and until World War 11 commanded wide support in the diaspora.’ The Jewish community is not a single united group and responses vary both among and within Jewish groups. One of the principal divisions is that between [[secular Jews]] and [[religious Jews]]. The reasons for secular opposition to the Zionist movement are very different from those of religious Jews. Opposition to a Jewish state has changed over time and has taken on a diverse spectrum of religious, ethical and political positions. The legitimacy of anti-Zionist views has been disputed to the present day, including the more recent and disputed relationship between anti-Zionism and [[antisemitism]].{{Cite journal |last=Wistrich |first=Robert S. |authorlink = Robert S. Wistrich |date=Fall 2004 |title=Anti-Zionism and Anti-Semitism |journal = Jewish Political Studies Review |volume = 16 |issue = 3–4 |issn = |url= http://old.jcpa.org/JCPA/Templates/ShowPage.asp?DRIT=3&DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=111&FID=625&PID=863&IID=1064&TTL=Anti-Zionism_and_Anti-Semitism |accessdate=26 February 2007 }}
 Other views regarding the various forms of anti-Zionism have also been discussed and debated.{{Cite journal |quotes = |last=Said |first=Edward |authorlink = Edward Said |date=November–December 2000 |title=America's Last Taboo |journal = [[New Left Review]] |volume = II |issue = 6 |pages=45–53 |issn = |url= http://newleftreview.org/II/6/edward-said-america-s-last-taboo |accessdate=26 February 2007 }} {{Cite book |last=Zipperstein |first=Steven J. |editor=[[Derek J. Penslar]] |editor2=[[Michael R. Marrus]] |editor3=[[Janice Gross Stein]] |title=Contemporary antisemitism: Canada and the world |accessdate=27 February 2007 |year=2005 |publisher=[[University of Toronto Press]] |location=Toronto, Ontario |isbn=978-0-8020-3931-6 |oclc = 56531591 |pages=60–61 |chapter=Historical Reflections on Contemporary Antisemitism |chapterurl = https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0802039316&id=Lmym8zUBCKcC&pg=RA1-PA60&lpg=RA1-PA60 |quote = |lccn=2005277647 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.jfjfp.org/ejjp/EUMC.htm |title=Letter sent to the European Monitoring Centre on Racism and Xenophobia concerning the Working Definition of Antisemitism |accessdate=26 February 2007 |last=Feiler |first=Dror |authorlink = Dror Feiler |date=13 October 2005 |publisher=European Jews for a Just Peace |quote = }} ===Before 1948=== There is a long tradition of Jewish anti-Zionism that has opposed the Zionist project from its origins. The [[Bundism|Bundists]], [[Jewish Autonomism|the Autonomists]], [[Reform Judaism]] and the [[World Agudath Israel|Agude]] regarded both the rationale and territorial ambitions of Zionism as flawed. [[Orthodox Judaism]], which grounds civic responsibilities and patriotic feelings in religion, was strongly opposed to Zionism because, though the two shared the same values, Zionism espoused nationalism in secular fashion, and used "Zion", "Jerusalem", "Land of Israel", "redemption" and "ingathering of exiles" as literal rather than sacred terms, endeavouring to achieve them in this world.S. Almog, [[Jehuda Reinharz]], [[Anita Shapira]] (eds.), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mS6oW4TTuwkC&pg=PA111 Zionism and Religion]'', UPNE, 1998 citing [[Isaac Breuer]],''Judenproblem'', Halle 1918 p. 89 Orthodox Jews also opposed the creation of a [[Jewish state]] prior to the appearance of the [[Messiah in Judaism|messiah]], as contradicting divine will.{{Cite book | last = Shapira | first = Anita |authorlink=Anita Shapira | title = Israel a history | publisher = Weidenfeld and Nicolson| location = London | page = 15 | date = 2014 | isbn =9780297871583}} By contrast, reform Jews rejected Judaism as a national or ethnic identity, and renounced any messianic expectations of the advent of a Jewish state.Ross [https://books.google.com/books?id=4zGOUAnfr5MC&pg=PA6 p. 6]. ====Religious==== Hope for return to the land of Israel is embodied in the content of the Jewish religion (see [[Kibbutz Galuyot]]). ''[[Aliyah]]'', the Hebrew word meaning "ascending" or "going up", is the word used to describe religious Jewish return to Israel, and has been used since ancient times. From the [[Middle Ages]] and onwards, many famous rabbis and often their followers returned to the land of Israel. These have included [[Nahmanides]], [[Yechiel of Paris]], [[Isaac Luria]], [[Yosef Karo]], [[Menachem Mendel of Vitebsk]] among others. For [[Jewish diaspora|Jews in the Diaspora]] ''[[Eretz Israel]]'' was revered in a religious sense. They prayed, and thought of the return, as being fulfilled in a messianic age.[[A. R. Taylor|Taylor, A. R.]], 1971, ''Vision and intent in Zionist Thought'', pp. 10, 11 Return remained a recurring theme for generations, particularly in [[Passover]] and [[Yom Kippur]] prayers, which traditionally concluded with, "[[Next year in Jerusalem]]", as well as the thrice-daily ''[[Amidah]]'' (Standing prayer).{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} Following [[Jewish Enlightenment]] however, [[Reform Judaism]] dropped many traditional beliefs, including ''aliyah'', as incompatible with modern life within the Diaspora. Later, Zionism re-kindled the concept of ''aliyah'' in an ideological and political sense, parallel with traditional religious belief; it was used to increase Jewish population in the Holy Land by immigration and it remains a basic tenet of Zionist ideology. Support for aliyah does not always equal immigration however, as a majority of the world Jewish population remains within the Diaspora. Support for the modern Zionist movement is not universal and, as a result, some religious Jews as well as some secular Jews do not support Zionism. [[Non-Zionism|Non-Zionist]] Jews are not necessarily anti-Zionists, although some are. Generally however, Zionism does have the support of the majority of the Jewish religious organizations, with support from segments of the [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] movement, and most of the [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative]], and more recently, the [[Reform Judaism|Reform]] movement.Rachael Gelfman, [http://www.myjewishlearning.com/ideas_belief/LandIsrael/modern_landisrael/ReligiousZionism.htm "Religious Zionists believe that the Jewish return to Israel hastens the Messiah"]Ehud Bandel – President, the Masorti Movement, [http://www.uscj.org/Zionism7161.html "Zionism"]{{cite web|url=http://ccarnet.org/Articles/index.cfm?id=42&pge_prg_id=4687&pge_id=1656 |title=Reform Judaism & Zionism: A Centenary Platform |date=27 October 2004 |publisher=[[Central Conference of American Rabbis]] |location=[[Miami]], [[Florida]] |access-date=8 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111125135118/http://ccarnet.org/Articles/index.cfm?id=42&pge_prg_id=4687&pge_id=1656 |archive-date=25 November 2011 |dead-url=yes }} Many [[Hasidic]] rabbis oppose the creation of a Jewish state. The leader of the [[Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)|Satmar]] Hasidic group, Rabbi [[Joel Teitelbaum]]'s book, ''[[Vayoel Moshe|VaYoel Moshe]]'', published in 1958, expounds one Orthodox position on Zionism, based on a literal form of ''[[midrash]]'' (biblical interpretation). Citing to Tractate Kesubos 111a of the [[Talmud]] Teitelbaum states that God and the Jewish people exchanged [[the Three Oaths|three oaths]] at the time of the Jews' exile from ancient Israel, forbidding the Jewish people from massively immigrating to the Land of Israel, and from rebelling against the nations of the world. ====Secular==== Prior to the Second World War many Jews regarded Zionism as a fanciful and unrealistic movement.[[Walter Laqueur]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=NMjh319vnwAC A History of Zionism]'', (Schocken Books, New York 1978, {{ISBN|0-8052-0523-3}}), pp385-6. Many liberals during the European [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] had argued that Jews should enjoy full equality only on the condition that they pledge their singular loyalty to their nation-state and entirely assimilate to the local national culture; they called for the "regeneration" of the Jewish people in exchange for rights. Those liberal Jews who accepted integration and/or assimilation principles saw Zionism as a threat to efforts to facilitate Jewish citizenship and equality within the European nation-state context.[[Walter Laqueur]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=NMjh319vnwAC A History of Zionism]'', p. 399. The [[Jewish Anti-Zionist League]], in Egypt, was a Communist-influenced anti-Zionist league in the years 1946–1947. In [[Israel]], there are several Jewish anti-Zionist organisations and politicians, many of these are related to [[Matzpen]].{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} ===After World War II and the creation of Israel=== Attitudes changed during and following the war. In May 1942, before the full revelation of the [[Holocaust]], the [[Biltmore Program]] proclaimed a fundamental departure from traditional Zionist policy of a "homeland"''American Jewish Year Book'' Vol. 45 (1943–1944) [http://www.ajcarchives.org/AJC_DATA/Files/1943_1944_5_USCivicPolitical.pdf "Pro-Palestine and Zionist Activities"], pp. 206–214 with its demand "that [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] be established as a Jewish Commonwealth". Opposition to official Zionism's firm, unequivocal stand caused some prominent Zionists to establish their own party, [[Ichud]] (Unification), which advocated an Arab – Jewish Federation in Palestine. Opposition to the Biltmore Program also led to the founding of the anti-Zionist [[American Council for Judaism]]. The full knowledge of the [[Holocaust]] altered the views of many who critiqued Zionism before 1948, including the British journalist [[Isaac Deutscher]], a socialist and lifelong [[atheist]] who nevertheless emphasised the importance of his Jewish heritage. Before [[World War II]], Deutscher opposed Zionism as economically retrograde and harmful to the cause of [[international socialism]], but in the aftermath of the Holocaust he regretted his pre-war views, arguing for Israel's establishment as a "historic necessity" to provide a refuge for the surviving [[Jews of Europe]]. In the 1960s, Deutscher renewed his criticism of Zionism, scrutinizing Israel for its failure to recognise the dispossession of the [[Palestinians]].{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} Other objections relate to the [[Demographics of Israel|maintenance of a Jewish majority]] within the present state of Israel. [[Post-Zionism]], a related term, has been criticized as being equivalent to anti-Zionism.{{cite web | url=http://www.meforum.org/185/post-zionism-and-israeli-politics | title=Post-Zionism and Israeli Politics: A briefing by Limor Livnat | publisher=Middle East Forum | date=August 2000}} ====Religious==== [[File:NKUSA.ORG at AIPAC protest 2005.JPG|thumb|300px|right|[[Neturei Karta]] call for dismantling of the state of Israel at AIPAC conference in Washington, DC, May 2005]] Most Orthodox religious groups have accepted and actively support the State of Israel, even if they have not adopted "Zionist" ideology. The [[World Agudath Israel]] party (founded in Poland) has at times participated in Israeli government coalitions. Most religious Zionists hold pro-Israel views from a right-wing viewpoint. The main exceptions are Hasidic groups such as [[Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)|Satmar]] Hasidim, which have about 100,000 adherents worldwide, as well as numerous different, smaller Hasidic groups, unified in America in the [[Central Rabbinical Congress of the United States and Canada]] and in Israel in the [[Edah HaChareidis]].[http://www.jewsagainstzionism.com Jews Against Zionism website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226024643/http://www.jewsagainstzionism.com/ |date=26 February 2009 }} Retrieved 4 June 2008.[http://www.truetorahjews.org/ Jews Against Zionism website] Retrieved 22 January 2013. [[David Novak]] writes that many Jewish anti-Zionists resent the way Zionism 'mak(es) ''Jewishly'' unwarranted claims on them and other Jews.[[David Novak]], 2015 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Q6WUBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA16 p. 16] According to [[Jonathan Judaken]], 'numerous Jewish traditions have insisted that preservation of what is most precious about Judaism and Jewishness "demands" a principled anti-Zionism or post-Zionism.' This tradition dwindled in the aftermath of the Holocaust, and the establishment of Israel but is still alive in religious groups such as [[Neturei Karta]] and among many intellectuals of Jewish background in both Israel and the diaspora, such as [[George Steiner]], [[Tony Judt]] and [[Baruch Kimmerling]] .[[Jonathan Judaken]], "Rethinking the New Antisemitism", in Jonathan Judaken (ed.), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=haraAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA215 Naming Race, Naming Racisms]'', Routledge, 2013 pp. 195-223 pp. 215-216. ====Secular==== [[Noam Chomsky]] has reported a change in the boundaries of what are considered Zionist and anti-Zionist views.[[James Peck (pacifist)|Peck, James]] (ed.) (1987). ''Chomsky Reader''. {{ISBN|0-394-75173-6}}. p. 7. "what was then called 'Zionist' ... are now called 'anti-Zionist' (concerns and views)". In 1947, in his youth, Chomsky's support for a socialist [[binational state]], in conjunction with his opposition to any semblance of a theocratic system of governance in Israel, was at the time considered well within the mainstream of secular Zionism; today, it lands him solidly in the anti-Zionist camp.[[James Peck (pacifist)|Peck, James]] (ed.) (1987). ''Chomsky Reader''. {{ISBN|0-394-75173-6}}. p. 7
"I was interested in socialist, binationalist options for Palestine, and in the kibbutzim and the whole cooperative labor system that had developed in the Jewish settlement there (the Yishuv).... The vague ideas I had at the time [1947] were to go to Palestine, perhaps to a kibbutz, to try to become involved in efforts at Arab-Jewish cooperation within a socialist framework, opposed to the deeply antidemocratic concept of a Jewish state."

[http://www.ajc.org/atf/cf/%7B42D75369-D582-4380-8395-D25925B85EAF%7D/PROGRESSIVE_JEWISH_THOUGHT.PDF 'Progressive' Jewish Thought and the New Anti-Semitism]. [[American Jewish Committee]]. 2006. claims that a "number of Jews, through their speaking and writing, are feeding a rise in virulent [[antisemitism]] by questioning whether [[Israel]] should even exist".Patricia Cohen. ''[[The New York Times]]''. 31 January 2007. Retrieved 19 March 2007. These charges are not true and can have the effect of delegitimizing Israel." Some Jewish organizations oppose Zionism as an integral part of their [[anti-imperialism]].{{cite web|title=The First National Jewish Anti-Zionist Gathering |url=http://www.jewsconfrontapartheid.org/ |publisher=Jews Confront Apartheid |accessdate=17 September 2010}}{{cite web|title=Not In Our Name ... Jewish voices opposing Zionism|url=http://www.nion.ca/|accessdate=17 September 2010}}{{cite web|title=Jews Against Zionism|url=http://www.jewsagainstzionism.org|accessdate=17 September 2010}}{{cite web|title=International Jewish Anti-Zionist Network |url=http://www.ijsn.net/home/ |accessdate=17 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://swap.stanford.edu/20091120000830/http%3A//www%2Eijsn%2Enet/home/ |archivedate=20 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Some secular Jews today, particularly socialists and [[Marxism|Marxists]], continue to oppose the State of Israel on anti-imperialist and human rights grounds. Many oppose it as a form of nationalism, which they argue to be a product of capitalist societies. One secular anti-Zionist group today is the [[International Jewish Anti-Zionist Network]], a socialist, anti-war, and anti-imperialist organization that calls for "the dismantling of Israeli apartheid, the return of Palestinian refugees, and the ending of the Israeli colonization of historic Palestine".{{cite web|title=Charter of the International Jewish anti-Zionist Network |url=http://www.ijsn.net/about_us/charter/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120804180125/http://www.ijsn.net/about_us/charter/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 August 2012 |publisher=International Jewish anti-Zionist Network |accessdate=29 October 2010 }} ==Outside the Jewish community== ===Palestinians=== Anne de Jong asserts that direct resistance from inhabitants of [[historic Palestine]] "focused less on religious arguments and was instead centred on countering the experience of colonial dispossession and opposing the Zionist enforcement of ethnic division of the indigenous population".{{cite journal|last1=Jong|first1=Anne de|title=Zionist hegemony, the settler colonial conquest of Palestine and the problem with conflict: a critical genealogy of the notion of binary conflict|journal=Settler Colonial Studies|date=3 May 2017|pages=1–20|doi=10.1080/2201473X.2017.1321171}} Palestinian Christian owned [[Falastin (newspaper)|Falastin]] was founded in 1911 in the then Arab-majority city of [[Jaffa]]. The newspaper is often described as one of the most influential newspapers in historic Palestine, and probably the nation's fiercest and most consistent critic of the [[Zionism|Zionist]] movement. It helped shape Palestinian identity and [[Palestinian Nationalism|nationalism]] and was shut down several times by the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] and [[Mandatory Palestine|British]] authorities, most of the time due to complaints made by Zionists.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bYADAQAAQBAJ&dq=rashid+khalidi+the+iron+cage&hl=ar&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=The Iron Cage: The Story of the Palestinian Struggle for Statehood|author=[[Rashid Khalidi]]|accessdate=25 January 2016|publisher=Beacon Press|date=9 January 2006}} ===British colonial officials=== The British anti-ZionistNaomi Wiener Cohen, [https://books.google.com/books?id=G2CL2-g4DM0C&pg=PA123 ''The Americanization of Zionism, 1897-1948,''] UPNE, 2003 p.123.[[John Hope Simpson]] believed that the Arabs were "economically powerless against such a strong movement" and thus needed protection. Charles Anderson writes that Hope Simpson was also "wary of the gulf between Zionist rhetoric and practice, observing that 'The most lofty sentiments are ventilated in public meetings and in Zionist [[Pan-Arabism|Pan-Arabist]] narratives in the 1960s [[Gamal Abdel Nasser|Nasser]] era emphasized the idea of Palestine as a part of the [[Arab world]] taken by others. In this narrative, the natural means of combating Zionism is Arab nations uniting and attacking Israel militarily. Most [[Arab citizens of Israel]] do not have strong anti-Zionist views. A poll of 507 [[Arab-Israeli]]s conducted by the [[Israeli Democracy Institute]] in 2007 found that 75 percent profess support for Israel's status as a [[Jewish and democratic state]] that guarantees equal rights for minorities. Israeli Arab support for a constitution in general was 88 percent.{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/853564.html |title=Poll of Arab-Israeli |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |accessdate=23 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070501032449/http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/853564.html |archivedate=1 May 2007 |df= }} ===Muslim=== [[File:روز جهانی قدس در شهر قم- Quds Day In Iran-Qom City 14.jpg|thumb|[[Quds Day]] demonstration in Qom, Iran]] Anti-Zionist Muslims consider the State of Israel as an intrusion into what many Muslims consider to be [[Dar al-islam|Dar al-Islam]], a domain they believe to be rightfully, and permanently, ruled only by Muslims due the fact it was historically conquered in the name of Islam.{{Cite book|last=Neusner |first=Jacob |authorlink=Jacob Neusner |title=Comparing Religions Through Law: Judaism and Islam |year=1999 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0-415-19487-3 }} p. 201{{Cite book|last=Merkley |first=Paul Charles |title=Christian Attitudes Towards the State of Israel |year=2001 |publisher=McGill-Queen's Press |isbn=0-7735-2188-7 }} p.122{{Cite book|last=Akbarzadeh |first=Shahram |authorlink=Shahram Akbarzadeh |title=Islam And the West: Reflections from Australia |year=2005 |publisher=UNSW Press |isbn=0-86840-679-1 }} p. 4 Palestinian and other Muslim groups, as well as the [[government of Iran]] (since the [[1979 Islamic Revolution]]), insist that the State of Israel is illegitimate and refuse to refer to it as "Israel", instead using the locution "the [[Zionist entity]]" (see [[Iran–Israel relations]]). ====Church of Scotland==== Despite its strong historic support for [[Christian Zionism|Restorationism]], famously by [[Robert Murray M'Cheyne|Robert Murray M'Chyene]] and by both [[Horatius The report further denied the "belief among some Jewish people that they have a right to the land of Israel as a compensation for the suffering of the Holocaust" and argued "it is a misuse of the Bible to use it as a topographic guide to settle contemporary conflicts over land." The report was criticised by Jewish leaders in Scotland as "biased, weak on sources, and contradictory.
